title: What's the real story?

content: quote: The thing is I have medical history that doesn't really apply to how I feel and am today. That's not your decision - that is the decision of the military medical team. Never, never o falsify an official document. Let's say they find out about it on a routine background check or worse yet a top secret check - if it's out there - they will find it. They will not wavier it! You will then be charged with falsification on an official document. You will be Court's Marshaled or boarded - out of service with less that an honorable discharge. Bad news! Read this and think about it 13a. My acceptance for enlistment is based on the information I have given in my application for enlistment. If any of that information is false or incorrect, this enlistment may be voided or terminated administratively by the Government or I may be tried by a Federal, civilian, or military court and, if found guilty, may be punished. DA form 4/2, OCT 2007 You can’t say, “I asked the guys on military.com (or anywhere else.) and they said I didn’t have to tell you everything.” God and the soldier, All men adore, In time of trouble, And no more; For when war is over, And all things righted, God is neglected - The old soldier slighted. Founding Member Original DVG & Proud Member, Rupterd Duck/Derelict Veterans

content: Around 1977 the Army was doing it's cut backs and went thru all the people in my unit's records. They redid all the background checks to see who they could cut. They found little things they didn't like and changed thier MOS's and some were released from the Army. So what I am saying that you may get away with it when you go in. but they will check on you again and again. Your clearance is what gets you better jobs. Many of the people were E-6 and E-7 that had troubles.
